title: Self Introduction
objectives: Practice saying your name and nationality
context: Now that you've learned basic greetings, it's time to introduce yourself! Being able to say who you are, where you're from, and what you do is essential in any language. In Korean culture, self-introductions are a key part of building relationships, whether in formal or casual settings.

Did you know? In Korea, it's common to introduce yourself with your full name and occupation or school when meeting someone for the first time. The level of detail you provide depends on the formality of the situation.

This lesson will teach you the fundamental building blocks for self-introduction. You'll learn about the topic particle (는/은), which is one of the most important particles in Korean grammar, and how to use basic identity statements.
explanation: 저 (jeo) is the formal way to say 'I' or 'me'. The informal version is 나 (na).
는/은 is a topic marking particle. Use 는 after vowels and 은 after consonants.
이에요/예요 means 'to be'. Use 이에요 after consonants and 예요 after vowels.
When introducing yourself, start with 저는 (jeoneun) which means 'As for me' or 'I'.
To ask someone's name, say 이름이 뭐예요? (What is your name?)
